elements.content: The Mg–Mg-bonded compound, [K­(THF)3]2[LMg–MgL] (1, L = [(2,6-iPr2C6H3)­NC­(Me)]2 2–), exhibits good reactivity toward a series of nitriles (RCN). Reaction of 1 with 2.0 equiv of Me3SiCN proceeded through reductive Si–C(CN) bond cleavage to generate the cyanide ions (CN–), which serve as bridges to link the tetrameric complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(THF)6] (2). When more (3.0 equiv) of the nitrile substrates Me3SiCN or tBuCN were reacted with 1, both Si–C(CN) [or C–C(CN)] bond cleavage and terminal coordination of the nitriles occurred, leading to the tetramers [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(RCN)2K4(THF)4] (R = Me3Si, 3 and R = tBu, 4). More interestingly, reaction of precursor 1 with 2.0 equiv of isobutyronitrile (iPrCN) or cyclohexyl nitrile (CyCN) that has α-hydrogen atoms afforded the dinuclear complexes [{K­(THF)2LMg­(μ-NCCMe2)}2] (6) and [{K­(Tol)­LMg­(μ-NCCC5H10)}2] (7) with bridging keteniminate ligands, representing a rare reductive deprotonation pathway for nitriles. All products were characterized by X-ray diffraction, NMR, and infrared spectra and density functional theory computations.

Reaction of 1 with 2.0 equiv of Me3SiCN proceeded through reductive Si-C(CN) bond cleavage to generate the cyanide ions (CN-), which serve as bridges to link the tetrameric complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(THF)6] (2). When more (3.0 equiv) of the nitrile substrates Me3SiCN or tBuCN were reacted with 1, both Si-C(CN) [or C-C(CN)] bond cleavage and terminal coordination of the nitriles occurred, leading to the tetramers [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(RCN)2K4(THF)4] (R = Me3Si, 3 and R = tBu, 4). More interestingly, reaction of precursor 1 with 2.0 equiv of isobutyronitrile (iPrCN) or cyclohexyl nitrile (CyCN) that has α-hydrogen atoms afforded the dinuclear complexes [{K(THF)2LMg(μ-NCCMe2)}2] (6) and [{K(Tol)LMg(μ-NCCC5H10)}2] (7) with bridging keteniminate ligands, representing a rare reductive deprotonation pathway for nitriles. All products were characterized by X-ray diffraction, NMR, and infrared spectra and density functional theory computations.

elements.content: The interaction of unsaturated molecules with metal ions is a vital first step in the transformation of these substrates, affording metal adducts that are often key intermediates of both stoichiometric and catalytic reactions. With the CN triple bond, nitriles (RCN) are widely used in organic synthesis, and there are a rich variety of coordination/activation pathways of nitriles by metal complexes. The “end-on” coordination of RCN to a metal (, type A) is a simple and common way. When the nitrile contains α-hydrogen atoms, deprotonation may occur to form the keteniminate fragment (type B). Moreover, cleavage of (R)­E–C(CN) (E = Si, C, etc.) bond to yield cyanide ions (type C), which serve as either bridging or terminal ligands, is a normal process leading to various (cyclic) complexes. There are also homo- and hetero- (with other groups such as CC bond) C–C couplings, e.g., reductive C–C coupling of two coordinated nitriles to form a five-membered metallocycle (type D in ). Besides these reaction routes, sometimes nitrile isomerization can occur to afford an isonitrile, which then coordinates to metal through the carbon atom or undergoes C–C coupling process.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The interaction of unsaturated molecules with metal ions is a vital first step in the transformation of these substrates, affording metal adducts that are often key intermediates of both stoichiometric and catalytic reactions. With the CN triple bond, nitriles (RCN) are widely used in organic synthesis, and there are a rich variety of coordination/activation pathways of nitriles by metal complexes. The "end-on" coordination of RCN to a metal (, type A) is a simple and common way. When the nitrile contains α-hydrogen atoms, deprotonation may occur to form the keteniminate fragment (type B). Moreover, cleavage of (R)E-C(CN) (E = Si, C, etc.) bond to yield cyanide ions (type C), which serve as either bridging or terminal ligands, is a normal process leading to various (cyclic) complexes. There are also homo- and hetero- (with other groups such as CC bond) C-C couplings, e.g., reductive C-C coupling of two coordinated nitriles to form a five-membered metallocycle (type D in ). Besides these reaction routes, sometimes nitrile isomerization can occur to afford an isonitrile, which then coordinates to metal through the carbon atom or undergoes C-C coupling process.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representations of Some Typical Bonding Modes in Metal Nitrile Complexes

elements.content: The reactivity of metal–metal-bonded compounds has attracted much attention because the low-valent metal centers have proven to facilitate novel reaction types toward a wide range of small molecules. For example, the Mg­(I)–Mg­(I)-bonded compounds have shown good reducing abilities and been used in the activation of unsaturated small molecules, such as isonitriles and nitriles, CO2, azides, and ketene OCCPh2. Oxidative addition of C–F bond of polyfluorinated arenes and reductive cleavage of esters by the dimagnesium­(I) species have also been reported. In a recent work, reversible insertion of a CC double bond to Mg–Mg bond was observed, while catalytic applications of such Mg­(I) species are also emerging. Especially, reactions of the β-diketiminate coordinated magnesium­(I) dimers, RMgMgR (R = [(Ar)­NC­(NiPr2)­N­(Ar)]−), with nitriles (and isonitriles) have been studied, which involved reaction types A, C and D in . Nevertheless, the reaction path B, i.e., deprotonation of α-hydrogen of nitriles, has not previously been reported for Mg–Mg-bonded compounds.
elements.clean_text: The reactivity of metal-metal-bonded compounds has attracted much attention because the low-valent metal centers have proven to facilitate novel reaction types toward a wide range of small molecules. For example, the Mg(I)-Mg(I)-bonded compounds have shown good reducing abilities and been used in the activation of unsaturated small molecules, such as isonitriles and nitriles, CO2, azides, and ketene OCCPh2. Oxidative addition of C-F bond of polyfluorinated arenes and reductive cleavage of esters by the dimagnesium(I) species have also been reported. In a recent work, reversible insertion of a CC double bond to Mg-Mg bond was observed, while catalytic applications of such Mg(I) species are also emerging. Especially, reactions of the β-diketiminate coordinated magnesium(I) dimers, RMgMgR (R = [(Ar)NC(NiPr2)N(Ar)]-), with nitriles (and isonitriles) have been studied, which involved reaction types A, C and D in . Nevertheless, the reaction path B, i.e., deprotonation of α-hydrogen of nitriles, has not previously been reported for Mg-Mg-bonded compounds.

elements.content: Our group has reported the Mg–Mg-bonded compound [K­(THF)3]2[LMg–MgL] (1) bearing doubly reduced α-diimine (enediamido) ligands (L = [(2,6-iPr2C6H3)­NC­(Me)]2 2–). Since the noninnocent α-diimine ligands can serve as electron reservoirs and participate in the reactions of their complexes, we recently set out to study the small-molecule activation properties of 1. In the present work, reactions of compound 1 with different nitriles were carried out, which afforded six products (complexes 2–7) through three reaction routes presented in , i.e., decomposition of nitrile to release cyanide ions as in the multinuclear complexes 2–4 (reaction type C, ), release of cyanide plus end-on coordination of RCN molecules (3 and 4, types A+C), and deprotonation of α-H to give ketiniminate ligands bridging two Mg centers (6 and 7, type B). Herein we report studies on these reactions and characterization of the products 2–7, including X-ray diffraction, NMR, and infrared (IR) spectra and density functional theory (DFT) computations.

Since the noninnocent α-diimine ligands can serve as electron reservoirs and participate in the reactions of their complexes, we recently set out to study the small-molecule activation properties of 1. In the present work, reactions of compound 1 with different nitriles were carried out, which afforded six products (complexes 2-7) through three reaction routes presented in , i.e., decomposition of nitrile to release cyanide ions as in the multinuclear complexes 2-4 (reaction type C, ), release of cyanide plus end-on coordination of RCN molecules (3 and 4, types A+C), and deprotonation of α-H to give ketiniminate ligands bridging two Mg centers (6 and 7, type B). Herein we report studies on these reactions and characterization of the products 2-7, including X-ray diffraction, NMR, and infrared (IR) spectra and density functional theory (DFT) computations.

elements.content: As illustrated in , reactions of the in situ generated magnesium­(I) precursor [K­(THF)3]2[LMg–MgL] (1) with different nitriles were studied. In all cases, oxidative cleavage of the Mg–Mg bond was observed to yield Mg2+ ions. Meanwhile, the nitrile molecule underwent different transformations (except for products 3 and 4 which contain two coordinating Me3SiCN or tBuCN molecules). All of the products are air- and moisture sensitive but are thermally stable under inert atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Complexes 2-5 by the Reaction of 1 with Nitriles

As illustrated in , reactions of the in situ generated magnesium(I) precursor [K(THF)3]2[LMg-MgL] (1) with different nitriles were studied. In all cases, oxidative cleavage of the Mg-Mg bond was observed to yield Mg2+ ions. Meanwhile, the nitrile molecule underwent different transformations (except for products 3 and 4 which contain two coordinating Me3SiCN or tBuCN molecules). All of the products are air- and moisture sensitive but are thermally stable under inert atmosphere.

elements.content: Reaction of 1 with 2 equiv of trimethylsilyl cyanide Me3SiCN in THF at room temperature afforded orange-red crystals of product [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(THF)6] (2). During the reaction, reductive cleavage of Si–C(CN) bond occurred, and the released cyanide ions (CN–) function as bridges to link two Mg atoms or one Mg and one K atom. Treatment of 1 with 3.0 equiv of Me3SiCN gave the tetranuclear magnesium complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(Me3SiCN)2K4(THF)4] (3), which not only involves bridging CN– ions as in 2 but also contains two Me3SiCN molecules coordinated to the two “terminal” Mg atoms. Similarly, the reaction of 1 with 3.0 equiv of tBuCN gave the complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(tBuCN)2K4(THF)4] (4) that is isostructural to 3. Nevertheless, in this case the other part of the broken nitrile, the tert-butyl group, was also captured by magnesium to form the mononuclear complex [K­(THF)3]­[LMg­(tBu)­(THF)] (5).
elements.clean_text: Reaction of 1 with 2 equiv of trimethylsilyl cyanide Me3SiCN in THF at room temperature afforded orange-red crystals of product [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(THF)6] (2). During the reaction, reductive cleavage of Si-C(CN) bond occurred, and the released cyanide ions (CN-) function as bridges to link two Mg atoms or one Mg and one K atom. Treatment of 1 with 3.0 equiv of Me3SiCN gave the tetranuclear magnesium complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(Me3SiCN)2K4(THF)4] (3), which not only involves bridging CN- ions as in 2 but also contains two Me3SiCN molecules coordinated to the two "terminal" Mg atoms. Similarly, the reaction of 1 with 3.0 equiv of tBuCN gave the complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4(tBuCN)2K4(THF)4] (4) that is isostructural to 3. Nevertheless, in this case the other part of the broken nitrile, the tert-butyl group, was also captured by magnesium to form the mononuclear complex [K(THF)3][LMg(tBu)(THF)] (5).

elements.content: Cyanide complex 2 shows a centrosymmetric structure containing four Mg2+ ions, four L ligands, four CN– ions originating from the nitrile, and four K+ ions (). The [CN]− moieties serve as bridges to link four [LMg] fragments and two K atoms. Each asymmetric unit features two Mg atoms with different coordination modes. One of them (Mg1) is penta-coordinated by a ligand L, the bridging CN– that connects to the other Mg atom, as well as two THF molecules, in a distorted square pyramidal arrangement. The other Mg atom (Mg2) resides on a tetrahedral environment, being coordinated by a chelating α-diimine ligand, the bridging CN–, and a “terminal” CN– ion. Notably, this “terminal” cyanide ligand is further end-on linked to a K+ ion (K1A in ) from another symmetry-related unit, which is coordinated by the CN π bonds of both CN ligands on Mg2A. Such a head-to-tail connection dimerizes the whole complex into the multicomponent molecule. There are two more “terminal” potassium ions, which interact with a CN ligand and the C2N2 backbone of one ligand L.
elements.clean_text:
[L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(THF)6] (2)

Cyanide complex 2 shows a centrosymmetric structure containing four Mg2+ ions, four L ligands, four CN- ions originating from the nitrile, and four K+ ions (). The [CN]- moieties serve as bridges to link four [LMg] fragments and two K atoms. Each asymmetric unit features two Mg atoms with different coordination modes. One of them (Mg1) is penta-coordinated by a ligand L, the bridging CN- that connects to the other Mg atom, as well as two THF molecules, in a distorted square pyramidal arrangement. The other Mg atom (Mg2) resides on a tetrahedral environment, being coordinated by a chelating α-diimine ligand, the bridging CN-, and a "terminal" CN- ion. Notably, this "terminal" cyanide ligand is further end-on linked to a K+ ion (K1A in ) from another symmetry-related unit, which is coordinated by the CN π bonds of both CN ligands on Mg2A. Such a head-to-tail connection dimerizes the whole complex into the multicomponent molecule. There are two more "terminal" potassium ions, which interact with a CN ligand and the C2N2 backbone of one ligand L.

elements.content: As mentioned above (), cutting off the R group from a nitrile RCN often results in multinuclear metallocycles with bridging cyanide ions by both of the C and N atoms. Interestingly, a number of cyclic trinuclear complexes with three cyanide bridges, e.g., [Cp*2Ce­(μ-CN)­(CNtBu)]3 and [(dipp-nacnac)­CaCN]3, resulting from nitriles (or other sources like cyanuric chloride or isonitriles) have been isolated, while the larger tetra-nuclear systems such as [MCN]4 (M = Al, Ga) are also known. Meanwhile, cyanide-bridged complexes are not restricted to homometals; heterometal species are also known, such as magnesium/iron and magnesium/uranium complexes. It is noteworthy that reactions of the β-diketiminate Mg­(I) dimers with nitriles/isonitriles afforded a trinuclear cyanide-bridged [Mg3] species, with a structure similar to above-mentioned analogues of Ti, Ca, Sm, Al, and so on. In this current work, while two of the cyanides bridge two Mg atoms, the other two ‘terminal” CN– ions indeed link one Mg and one K ion, which is different from the reported examples, reflecting the similar ionic interaction of K+ or Mg2+ to CN–.

Meanwhile, cyanide-bridged complexes are not restricted to homometals; heterometal species are also known, such as magnesium/iron and magnesium/uranium complexes. It is noteworthy that reactions of the β-diketiminate Mg(I) dimers with nitriles/isonitriles afforded a trinuclear cyanide-bridged [Mg3] species, with a structure similar to above-mentioned analogues of Ti, Ca, Sm, Al, and so on. In this current work, while two of the cyanides bridge two Mg atoms, the other two ‘terminal" CN- ions indeed link one Mg and one K ion, which is different from the reported examples, reflecting the similar ionic interaction of K+ or Mg2+ to CN-.

elements.content: The molecular structure of complex 2 reveals an obvious CN triple bond length (N5–C9: 1.160(5) Å) of the two cyanide groups between two Mg atoms, which is slightly longer than the other cyanides (N6–C10: 1.148(5) Å) that bridge Mg and K atoms. These bond lengths are comparable to those of bridging cyanides in related complexes, e.g., the β-diketiminate magnesium trimers (avg 1.167 Å) and the trimeric dialkylgallium cyanide (avg 1.152 Å). Notably, as in many reported cases, it is impossible to distinguish the carbon and nitrogen atoms of the bridging CN– ligands between two Mg atoms in the crystal structure, and they were isotropically refined with 50% C and 50% N occupation. However, the C and N atoms of the “terminal” CN– ions (that link Mg and K atoms) can be refined individually. The α-diimine ligands show the CC double-bond (avg 1.359 Å) and C–N single-bond (1.416 Å) character of the central C2N2 backbone, indicating that they remain dianionic (L2–) as in precursor 1. Thus, it appears that the reductive cleavage of Me3Si–CN (and tBu–CN, vide infra) bond is promoted by the Mg­(I) ion.

These bond lengths are comparable to those of bridging cyanides in related complexes, e.g., the β-diketiminate magnesium trimers (avg 1.167 Å) and the trimeric dialkylgallium cyanide (avg 1.152 Å). Notably, as in many reported cases, it is impossible to distinguish the carbon and nitrogen atoms of the bridging CN- ligands between two Mg atoms in the crystal structure, and they were isotropically refined with 50% C and 50% N occupation. Thus, it appears that the reductive cleavage of Me3Si-CN (and tBu-CN, vide infra) bond is promoted by the Mg(I) ion.

elements.content: The 1H NMR (in THF-d 8, ) spectrum of 2 displays sharp and clear signals of the α-diimine ligands (L2–), in which the alkyl groups appear at 1.04, 1.13, 1.47, and 3.90 ppm, while the aromatic hydrogens are located at 6.47 and 6.75 ppm. The 13C NMR spectrum shows peaks corresponding to the ligands. Notably, the characteristic peak of the CN is not observed. Such an absence of the CN signal was also reported in related cyanide-bridged complexes, e.g., [(DipNacnac)­Mg­(μ-CN)]3 and [Cp’2SmCN]6, although this was found to appear at 158.1 ppm in the 13C NMR spectrum of [(dipp-nacnac)­CaCN·THF]3. Nevertheless, the IR spectrum of 2 displays absorption peaks at 2148 and 2090 cm–1 corresponding to the CN stretch, which are smaller than those of [(DipNacnac)­Mg­(μ-CN)]3 (2281 and 2157 cm–1). Moreover, DFT computations were carried out on the model compound [L′4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(H2O)6] (2H, L′ = [PhNC­(Me)]2) (). The theoretical N5–C9 (1.168 Å) and N6–C10 (1.176 Å) distances of CN are close to the X-ray values (1.159(5) and 1.148(5) Å), with bond orders of 2.79 and 2.70, respectively. In the C2N2 backbone of α-diimine ligands the calculated C1–C2 (1.372 Å) and C5–C6 (1.373 Å) bond orders are 1.63, while the N–C bonds display the σ-bond order of 1.09 and 1.10, corresponding to dianion [ArN–CC–NAr]2–.

elements.content: When precursor 1 was reacted with 3.0 equiv of Me3SiCN, tetranuclear cyanide–nitrile complex 3 was isolated as an orange-red crystalline solid. Complex 3 presents a main structure similar to that of 2, with both tetra- and penta-coordinate Mg atoms and bridging cyanide ions. The difference is that there are two additional Me3SiCN molecules in 3, which coordinate through the N terminal to two of the Mg atoms (the penta-coordinate ones) (). It can be viewed as one of the coordinated THF molecules (on Mg1, ) in product 2 being replaced by a nitrile molecule in 3. The four magnesium atoms and four potassium atoms are nearly coplanar.

[L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(NCSiMe3)2(THF)4] (3), [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(NCtBu)2(THF)4] (4), and [K(THF)3][LMg(tBu)(THF)] (5)

When precursor 1 was reacted with 3.0 equiv of Me3SiCN, tetranuclear cyanide-nitrile complex 3 was isolated as an orange-red crystalline solid. Complex 3 presents a main structure similar to that of 2, with both tetra- and penta-coordinate Mg atoms and bridging cyanide ions. The difference is that there are two additional Me3SiCN molecules in 3, which coordinate through the N terminal to two of the Mg atoms (the penta-coordinate ones) (). It can be viewed as one of the coordinated THF molecules (on Mg1, ) in product 2 being replaced by a nitrile molecule in 3. The four magnesium atoms and four potassium atoms are nearly coplanar.

elements.content: Similar reaction of 1 with 3.0 equiv of tBuCN, which has almost the same steric bulk as Me3SiCN, yielded analogous product 4 with a structure very similar to that of 3 () except for the coordinated nitrile molecules (Me3SiCN in 3 versus tBuCN in 4). Notably, another product, the mononuclear alkyl complex [K­(THF)3]­[LMg­(tBu)­(THF)] (5), was also obtained together with 4, indicating the reaction pathway to be two-electron reductive cleavage of C–C bond to yield tBu– and CN– ions that are both trapped by the Mg­(II) centers. In contrast, in the parallel reaction of 1 with Me3SiCN (either 2.0 or 3.0 equiv), related silyl (Me3Si−) analogue was not isolated, which might reflect the instability of the silyl complex. However, 29Si NMR spectrum indicates the formation of some byproducts that could not be identified. Moreover, attempts to synthesize solely cyanide-bridged species 2 by treating 1 with 2.0 equiv of tBuCN did not give any isolable product. This situation is somewhat similar to the β-diketiminate Mg­(I) compounds, which also gave the mononuclear alkyl complex [RMg­(tBu)­(NCtBu)] (together with the Mg3 metallocycle) in the reaction with tBuCN but not the silyl species in that with Me3SiCN. In the latter case, however, a C–C coupling product was obtained. A slight difference between [RMg­(tBu)­(NCtBu)] and complex 5 is that the former contains a coordinated tBuCN molecule while in 5 the Mg­(II) coordination sphere is completed by a solvent THF. Besides this reductive cleavage pathway, a one-electron route involving tBu radical from homolysis of tBu–CN was previously proposed in the case of nitrile reduction by Sm­(II) complexes.

elements.content: The molecular structures of complexes 3–5 are depicted in , , and , respectively. Indeed, the terminal coordination of nitriles to metal ions found in 3 and 4 is not unusual. In addition, the structures of 3 and 4 are similar to the products yielded from the reduction of nitrile tBuCN (or isonitrile tBuNC) with [Cp*2Sm­(THF)2], generating [Cp*2Sm­(NCtBu)­(μ-CN)]3 or [Cp*2Sm­(CNtBu)­(μ-CN)]3 that have both terminal nitrile/isonitrile and bridging cyanide ions. Within the Mg4(μ-CN)4K2 backbone of complex 3, the CN bond length (N5–C9, 1.172(3) Å, ) of the cyanide ion between two Mg atoms is comparable to that in 2 (1.160(5) Å). In contrast, as the same trend found in complex 2, the CN bonds (N6–C10, 1.153(3) Å) bridging an Mg and a K atom is also shorter in 3. The CN triple bond length (N7–C11, 1.150(3) Å) of the two terminal N-coordinated Me3SiCN molecules is even shorter than that of the bridging CN ions and is close to that of some similar complexes with coordinated nitriles.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectrum of 3 shows evidence of six methyl groups of coordinated Me3SiCN as a sharp signal at 0.33 ppm. In the 13C NMR, the signal of the TMS group (Si­(CH3)3) appears at −2.2 ppm, which shifts slightly to higher upfield compared to the free (CH3)3SiCN (δ = −1.82) in a CDCl3 solution, while the two signals at 201.9 and 149.8 ppm correspond to the coordinated nitrile and the bridging CN– ion, respectively. The IR spectrum of 3 exhibits two absorptions in the υCN region at 2088 (bridging CN–) and 2145 cm–1 (coordinated Me3SiCN), similar to those of the analogue [Cp*2La­(μ-CN)­(NCSiMe3)]3 (2104 and 2178 cm–1 for the bridging cyanide ions and coordinated Me3SiCN molecule, respectively).

elements.content: In complex [L4Mg4(μ-CN)4K4(NCtBu)2(THF)4] (4), as with 3, the CN triple bond (N7–C11, 1.132(5) Å) of the coordinated NCtBu is the shortest among the three types of CN unit. The 1H NMR spectrum of 4 presents a sharp signal at 1.31 ppm for the tert-butyl groups of the coordinated nitrile, which shifts downfield compared to that (δ = 0.99 ppm) of the similarly coordinated tBuCN in [(DipNacnac)­Mg­(tBu)­(NCtBu)]. The IR spectrum shows CN stretching at 2090, 2157, and 2277 cm–1, corresponding to the bridging CN– and end-on nitrile, respectively, the latter of which is larger than that of free tBuCN (2231 cm–1). The 13C NMR spectrum of 4 reveals two CN signals, one (δ = 229.4 ppm) for the end-on coordinated tBuCN and the other (δ = 145.9 ppm) for the bridging CN– ions. The former is similar to the isocyanide groups (δ = 248.2 ppm) in the titanium compounds with end-on bonded isonitrile [rac-(ebthi)­Ti­((η1-CNXy)2)] (rac-(ebthi) = rac-1,2-ethylene-1,1′-bis­(η5-tetrahydroindenyl), Xy = 2,6-dimethylphenyl).

elements.content: In complex 5 (), the Mg atom sits in a tetrahedral environment consisting of a chelating α-diimine ligand, a THF molecule and a tBu– group. A solvated K­(THF)3 + ion interacts with an aryl ring of the ligand. The successful capture of the tert-butyl group further illustrates the reductive bond cleavage of tBuCN. The α-diimine ligand in 5 retains the dianionic form, with a calculated natural charge of −1.80 and CC bond order of 1.61 and N–C bond orders of 1.13 and 1.05 as revealed by DFT. Besides, the observed shift downfield (δ = 36.7 ppm) in the 13C NMR spectrum indicates the coordination of tert-butyl to Mg atom, while the 1H NMR (THF-d 8) spectrum displays a resonance at 0.66 ppm consistent with the presence of a tBu unit.

elements.content: Interestingly, in the cases of nitriles bearing α-hydrogen atoms, i.e., isobutyronitrile Me2CHCN and cyclohexanecarbonitrile C6H11CN, the reaction with 1 proceeded via a different pathway. Upon addition of 2.0 equiv of Me2CHCN (or C6H11CN) to a solution of complex 1 in THF at room temperature, an immediate color change from dark red to light-red was observed, and orange crystals of the dinuclear complex [{K­(THF)2LMg­(NCCMe2)}2] (6), infinite structure of [K2{LMg­(NCCMe2)}2]∞ (6′), and dinuclear [{K­(Tol)­LMg (NCCC5H10)}2] (7) were obtained after crystallization at ca. −30 °C. All of these products are formed upon α-H deprotonation (type B, ) and feature two μ2-NCCR′ ligands that bridge the two Mg atoms through the terminal imine N atom (). During the reactions, gas bubbles were generated, and dihydrogen gas was detected by gas chromatography on a FuLi 9790 II instrument, indicating the reductive elimination of H2.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complexes 6, 6', and 7 by the Reaction of 1 with Nitriles Bearing α-Hydrogen Atoms

Interestingly, in the cases of nitriles bearing α-hydrogen atoms, i.e., isobutyronitrile Me2CHCN and cyclohexanecarbonitrile C6H11CN, the reaction with 1 proceeded via a different pathway. Upon addition of 2.0 equiv of Me2CHCN (or C6H11CN) to a solution of complex 1 in THF at room temperature, an immediate color change from dark red to light-red was observed, and orange crystals of the dinuclear complex [{K(THF)2LMg(NCCMe2)}2] (6), infinite structure of [K2{LMg(NCCMe2)}2]∞ (6'), and dinuclear [{K(Tol)LMg (NCCC5H10)}2] (7) were obtained after crystallization at ca. -30 °C. All of these products are formed upon α-H deprotonation (type B, ) and feature two μ2-NCCR' ligands that bridge the two Mg atoms through the terminal imine N atom (). During the reactions, gas bubbles were generated, and dihydrogen gas was detected by gas chromatography on a FuLi 9790 II instrument, indicating the reductive elimination of H2.

elements.content: Complex 6 shows a centrosymmetric structure (). Each Mg atom sits in a distorted tetrahedral arrangement containing four nitrogen atoms from one chelating α-diimine ligand and two bridging keteniminate (NCCMe2) units, forming a planar rhombic Mg2N2 ring (N3–Mg1–N3A angle: 85.29(8)°; Mg1–N3–Mg1A: 94.72(8)°). This four-membered ring is perpendicular to the five-membered chelating MgC2N2 ring of ligand L, with a dihedral angle of 89.8°. The structure clearly shows the CN and CC double bond lengths (C29–N3, 1.228(3) Å; C29–C30, 1.326(4) Å), proving the presence of the keteniminate moiety. This is further supported by the IR spectrum exhibiting a strong sharp signal of NCC fragment at 2014 cm–1. Besides, the 13C NMR spectrum displays two resonances (δ = 143.6, 122.4 ppm) for the [NCC] ligand. Two solvated potassium ions [K­(THF)2]+ are bound to the dianionic α-diimine ligands in a way frequently seen for the doubly reduced L2–, plus interactions with the CC bond in the NCC moiety.

elements.content: In addition to the discrete dinuclear molecule of 6, infinite structure 6′ () was also obtained in a toluene solution. The main structure of the repeating unit, {LMg­(NCCMe2)}2, is essentially the same as that of 6. The difference lies only in the interactions of the K+ ions, which are anchored to the dianionic α-diimine backbones in 6 with supplementary solvation by THF. However, with the weakly coordinating solvent toluene, the potassium ion forms intermolecular interactions with the electron-rich aromatic rings and unsaturated bonds [NCC] in adjacent ligands, thus leading to the infinite structure of 6′. Such a phenomenon is indeed quite common in the systems containing dianionic α-diimine ligands and alkali metal ions. The bond lengths of [NCC] are only marginally varied (C29–N3, 1.211(3) Å; C29–C30, 1.322(3) Å) compared to those in 6 (1.228(3) and 1.326(4) Å).

elements.content: Although such a deprotonation of nitriles has been reported in the literature, structural data of the resulting keteniminate complexes are still rare. In a couple of available examples with nitriles like Ph2CHCN and CH3CN, characterization of the products is described. For transition metals, group 4 metallocenes, iridium and scandium complexes, and so on have been shown to deprotonate nitriles. For instance, treatment of [Cp*2Zr­(η2-Me3SiCCSiMe3)] with 2 equiv of Ph2CHCN yielded the product [Cp*2Zr­(NCCPh2)­(NCHCHPh2)], whose 13C NMR spectrum shows two peaks (δ = 160.4, 55.9 ppm) indicating the identity of [NCC] group and the IR spectrum of which shows a strong band at 2048 cm–1. In complex [Cp*­(PMe3)­Ir­(NCC­(Ph)2)­Ph] obtained from reaction of Cp*­(PMe3)­IrPh­(OH) with Ph2CHCN, the 13C resonances of NCC moiety appear at 129.7 and 142.6 ppm, the former of which was assigned to the middle C atom in [NCC], and the latter to the terminal C in [NCC]. In addition to transition metals, main group metal mediated generation of keteniminate is also known. Alkaline metal complexes bearing the keteniminate moiety, [(Ar-bianH)­M­(NCCPh2)­(Sol)2] (M = Mg, Sr, Ba), were obtained from reactions of Ph2CHCN with corresponding [(Ar-Bian)­M­(Sol) n ] precursors. A magnesium complex with a diphenylketeniminate ligand was obtained in the study of nitrile hydroboration catalyzed by the β-diketiminato n-butylmagnesium species. The lithium compounds [(PhCHCN)­Li2N­(C­(Me3)2)2] and [(Ph2CCN)­Li­(Et2O)2]2, as well as gallium species [(Ph2CCN)­GaMe2]2 (CCN at 55.1 and 140.0 ppm in 13C NMR) and indium analogue [(Ph2CCN)­InMe2(THF)]2 (55.0 and 141.2 ppm in 13C NMR), have also been derived from different nitriles. These heteroallyls were found to behave as proton acceptors or as protonation agents and to undergo C–C couplings between the α-C of one keteniminate and the β-C of the other, producing the elongated C,N-chain.

elements.content: However, this reaction type has not been reported for Mg–Mg-bonded compounds. Moreover, in the above cases, the deprotonation is promoted mainly by two processes. The most common one is the use of an extra base (amide, alkyl, H–, or OH– etc.) to abstract the proton with the elimination of amine and alkane, and so on, and one example is the above-mentioned reaction of BuLi with Ph2CHCN that yielded diphenylketeniminate ligands upon elimination of butane. The other method for nitrile deprotonation is the intramolecular hydrogen transfer to a basic group, such as in the case of the [(Ar-bianH)­M­(NCCPh2)­(Sol)2] complexes wherein the proton is shifted to one N atom of the Ar-Bian ligands (to form Ar-bianH). Thus, the current work may represent a rare example of a new pathway for this process, i.e., by reductive dehydrogenation (to eliminate H2), thus demonstrating the promising reactivity of the Mg­(I) species 1.

The most common one is the use of an extra base (amide, alkyl, H-, or OH- etc.) to abstract the proton with the elimination of amine and alkane, and so on, and one example is the above-mentioned reaction of BuLi with Ph2CHCN that yielded diphenylketeniminate ligands upon elimination of butane. The other method for nitrile deprotonation is the intramolecular hydrogen transfer to a basic group, such as in the case of the [(Ar-bianH)M(NCCPh2)(Sol)2] complexes wherein the proton is shifted to one N atom of the Ar-Bian ligands (to form Ar-bianH). Thus, the current work may represent a rare example of a new pathway for this process, i.e., by reductive dehydrogenation (to eliminate H2), thus demonstrating the promising reactivity of the Mg(I) species 1.

elements.content: Complex 7 exhibits a centrosymmetric dinuclear structure () similar to that of 6. The bonding situation of the keteniminate unit (C29–N3, 1.215(2) Å; C29–C30, 1.332(2) Å) is close to that of analogues 6 and 6′, with a slightly longer CC and comparable NC bond, which may be caused by the steric effect of the substituent on nitrile. In complex 7, the central Mg2N2 plane is also orthogonal to the MgN2C2 ring (dihedral angle is 88.8°). Unexpectedly, the K+ ions capped on the α-diimine C2N2 backbone are further π-bonded by the phenyl ring of a solvent toluene, thus interrupting the aggregation of individual complex molecules to form an infinite structure like that of 6′. This is in contrast to the commonly seen situation mentioned above and might be attributed to the large cyclohexyl substituent that prevents the approach of another complex molecule. The 13C NMR spectrum of 7 in THF-d 8 displays resonances at 145.2 and 122.4 ppm corresponding to the middle and terminal C atoms of the [CCN] group. Its IR spectrum shows a band at 2005 cm–1 for the keteniminate ligand. This value is smaller than that of complex 6 but falls in the range (2000–2200 cm–1) reported for similar compounds.

elements.content: To further understand the electronic structure of 6 and 7, DFT computations were carried out on the model compounds [{K­(H2O)2L′Mg­(NCCMe2)}2] (6H) and [{K­(Tol)­L′Mg­(NCCC5H10)}2] (7H) (L′ = [PhNMe]2, ). The calculated geometries are consistent with those determined by X-ray diffraction. In the C2N2 backbone of α-diimine ligand, the calculated C1–C2 (1.379 Å in 6H, 1.373 Å in 7H) bond order is 1.61 and 1.63, respectively, and the N–C bonds (1.420 Å in 6H, avg 1.421 Å in 7H) display the almost same bond order of 1.10 (in 6H) and 1.10 and 1.08 (in 7H), corresponding to the dianion [ArN–CC–NAr]2–. Natural population analysis (NPA) suggests that the natural charge on Mg is the same (+1.68 in 6H and 7H). The α-diimine ligands bear natural charges of −1.76 (in 6H) and average of −1.75 (in 7H), while the bridging keteniminate ligands show negative charges of −0.85 in both 6H and 7H. These results provide further evidence for the reductive dehydrogenation of the nitriles to generate Mg­(II) centers and negative [CCN–] moieties.

elements.content: Herein we presented studies of the reactions of an α-diimine-supported Mg–Mg bond compound with nitriles, which gave a series of products through different transformations, depending mainly on the substituent of nitrile. The reaction of 1 with trimethylsilyl cyanide and trimethylacetonitrile undergoes a reductive cleavage of the Si–C or C–C bond to generate the cyanide ion, leading to the formation of 2, 3, and 4 containing bridging CN– ions (and end-on coordinated nitrile as ligand). Dinuclear species 6 and 7 were obtained when compound 1 was reacted with isobutyronitrile and cyclohexyl nitrile, respectively, wherein the nitrile was converted to keteniminate through a rare reductive dehydrogenation of the α-H. In both cases, the transformations are promoted by the magnesium­(I) centers. These results prove the excellent reactivity of Mg–Mg-bonded compound 1, and further studies on its reactions with other molecules are ongoing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Herein we presented studies of the reactions of an α-diimine-supported Mg-Mg bond compound with nitriles, which gave a series of products through different transformations, depending mainly on the substituent of nitrile. The reaction of 1 with trimethylsilyl cyanide and trimethylacetonitrile undergoes a reductive cleavage of the Si-C or C-C bond to generate the cyanide ion, leading to the formation of 2, 3, and 4 containing bridging CN- ions (and end-on coordinated nitrile as ligand). Dinuclear species 6 and 7 were obtained when compound 1 was reacted with isobutyronitrile and cyclohexyl nitrile, respectively, wherein the nitrile was converted to keteniminate through a rare reductive dehydrogenation of the α-H. In both cases, the transformations are promoted by the magnesium(I) centers. These results prove the excellent reactivity of Mg-Mg-bonded compound 1, and further studies on its reactions with other molecules are ongoing.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All reactions and manipulations of the compounds described were performed under an Ar atmosphere in a glovebox or using Schlenk techniques under an N2 atmosphere. The solvents (THF and toluene) were distilled over molten sodium under N2 prior to use. Compound 1 was prepared according to the published procedures. NMR spectra were recorded on a Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer in THF-d 8. IR spectra were recorded in Nujol oil using KBr plates as the infrared transmission window on a Nicolet AVATAR 360 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were carried out on an Elementar VarioEL III instrument.

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared in situ by the reaction of α-diimine ligand L, MgCl2, and K metal. Trimethylsilyl cyanide (0.15 mL, 1.20 mmol) was added to the THF solution of compound 1, and the mixture was stirred for 3 days to give a deep red solution. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated to approximately 5 mL. A few drops of n-hexane were added, and the solution was stored at room temperature for several days to afford orange-red crystals of complex 2. Crystal yield: 356.8 mg (57.2%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ/ppm 1.04 (br, 48H, CH­(CH 3)2), 1.13 (br, 48H, CH­(CH 3)2), 1.47 (s, 24H, CH 3C), 3.90 (br, 16H, CH(CH3)2), 6.47 (br, 8H, p-C6H3), 6.75 (br, 16H, m-C6H3), 1.77, 3.62 (THF), 0.89, 1.28 (n-hexane). 13C NMR (100.6 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ/ppm 14.4 (NCCH3), 24.0 (CH­(CH3)2), 24.2 (CH­(CH3)2), 28.4 (CH­(CH3)2), 117.8 (p-C6H3), 123.6 (m-C6H3), 125.1 (o-C6H3), 139.6 (NC6H3), 145.2 (NCCN), 26.2, 68.0 (THF). IR (Nujol, ν/cm–1): 2926, 2861, 2148, 2090, 1588, 1462, 1251, 1035, 782. Elemental analysis calcd for C116H160K4Mg4N12·6THF·n-hexane (C146H222K4Mg4N12O6, 2494.98): C, 70.28; H, 8.97; N, 6.74%. Found: C, 70.02; H, 9.08; N, 6.51%.
